newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish PM lauds constitution ahead of vote.
newsitem.headline: Polish PM lauds constitution ahead of vote.

text.p: Prime Minister Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz on Saturday praised Poland's new draft constitution and rebuffed its critics ahead of a national referendum set for May 25.
"We face the prospect of having a basic law friendly to people that does not impose a worldview or way of life on anyone," he said on prime time public television.
"It is a mature and modern constitution...guaranteeing basic rights and liberties...which, in addition to those found in all democratic constitutions, contains certain new rights.
These include the right of citizens to lodge complaints with a special tribunal, if they feel their constitutional rights have been violated.
"Every group of 100,000 citizens will now have the right the submit their own bills to parliament," he added.
But Cimoszewicz, an ex-communist, said he was irritated by what he called "nonsensical arguments" against the constitution.
"They include scaring people that their children will be taken away, the Church will be persecuted and Poland will lose its sovereignty."

In the referendum, Poles will be able to approve or reject the parliamentary draft. Parliament has refused to consider a proposal to include an alternative draft prepared by the right-leaning Solidarity movement.

The pro-Catholic right has criticised the draft for not giving precedence to "natural law" (Christian values) over man-made legislation and failing to protect human life from the moment of conception.
It also complains that the draft constitution limits the influence of trade unions in solving labour disputes.
"Together, on May 25, we shall decide the fate of a good constitution, of which we will not have to be ashamed either tomorrow or many years from now," Cimoszewicz concluded his address.
